jsat.linear.distancemetrics

Class KernelDistance

  • java.lang.Object
    • jsat.linear.distancemetrics.KernelDistance
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, DistanceMetric

    public class KernelDistance
extends java.lang.Object
implements DistanceMetric
    Creates a distance metric from a given kernel trick. For the distance metric to be valid, the kernel used must be positive definite.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      KernelDistance(KernelTrick kf)
      Creates a distane metric from the given kernel.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      KernelDistance clone() 
      double dist(Vec a, Vec b)
      Returns the square of the distance function expanded as kernel methods.
      boolean isIndiscemible()
      Returns true if this distance metric obeys the rule that, for any x and y ∈ S
      d(x, y) = 0 if and only if x = y
      boolean isSubadditive()
      Returns true if this distance metric obeys the rule that, for any x, y, and z ∈ S
      d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z)
      boolean isSymmetric()
      Returns true if this distance metric obeys the rule that, for any x, y, and z ∈ S
      d(x, y) = d(y, x)
      double metricBound()
      All metrics must return values greater than or equal to 0.
      java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a descriptive name of the Distance Metric in use

    • Constructor Detail

      • KernelDistance

        public KernelDistance(KernelTrick kf)
        Creates a distane metric from the given kernel. For the metric to be valid, the kernel must be positive definite. This means that

        ∀ ci ∈ ℜ , xi ∈ ℜd
        ∑i, j = 1m ci cj K(xi, xj) ≥ 0
        Parameters:
        kf -

    • Method Detail

      • dist

        public double dist(Vec a,
          Vec b)
        Returns the square of the distance function expanded as kernel methods.
        d2(x,y) = K(x,x) - 2*K(x,y) + K(y,y)

        Special Notes:
        The use of RBFKernel or PolynomialKernel of degree 1 in the NearestNeighbour classifier will degenerate into the normal nearest neighbor algorithm.
        Specified by:
        dist in interface DistanceMetric
        Parameters:
        a - the first vector
        b - the second vector
        Returns:
        the distance metric based on a kernel function

      • isSymmetric

        public boolean isSymmetric()
        Description copied from interface: DistanceMetric
        Returns true if this distance metric obeys the rule that, for any x, y, and z ∈ S
        d(x, y) = d(y, x)
        Specified by:
        isSymmetric in interface DistanceMetric
        Returns:
        true if this distance metric is symmetric, false if it is not

      • isSubadditive

        public boolean isSubadditive()
        Description copied from interface: DistanceMetric
        Returns true if this distance metric obeys the rule that, for any x, y, and z ∈ S
        d(x, z) ≤ d(x, y) + d(y, z)
        Specified by:
        isSubadditive in interface DistanceMetric
        Returns:
        true if this distance metric supports the triangle inequality, false if it does not.

      • isIndiscemible

        public boolean isIndiscemible()
        Description copied from interface: DistanceMetric
        Returns true if this distance metric obeys the rule that, for any x and y ∈ S
        d(x, y) = 0 if and only if x = y
        Specified by:
        isIndiscemible in interface DistanceMetric
        Returns:
        true if this distance metric is indicemible, false otherwise.

      • metricBound

        public double metricBound()
        Description copied from interface: DistanceMetric
        All metrics must return values greater than or equal to 0. The upper bound on the value returned is different for different metrics. This method returns the theoretical maximal value that could be returned by this distance metric. That means Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY is a valid return value.
        Specified by:
        metricBound in interface DistanceMetric
        Returns:
        the maximal distance for any two points in that could exist by this distance metric.
